awd_titl_txt: Molecular Mechanisms in Adhesion Protein Mediated Neuron-Neuron Recognition
awd_abstract_narration:
How neurons interact with one another to create the complex wiring diagram of a mature vertebrate brain is a major mystery. One of the many problems that arises is how neurons are "barcoded"; that is, how they distinguish self from non-self. This ability is essential since, without it, there would be nothing to prevent neurons from forming connections (synapses) with themselves, essentially creating a short circuit within the brain. The fundamental goal of this project is to understand how neurons are barcoded. Neuron-neuron recognition is mediated by protein-protein interactions. This project focuses on members of the Clustered Protocadherins (Pcdh) protein family that establish a unique identity for individual vertebrate neurons allowing them to distinguish "self" from "non-self".  The research will involve computer simulations, biophysical measurements, and high-resolution microscopy experiments to experimentally validate and describe the barcoding mechanism in cells.   A particularly important element of the research is the development of scientists with expertise in both computational and experimental work. The training of women and minority scientists is an integral component of the proposed research program. Both undergraduate and graduate minority students trained to be on a trajectory to become highly successful research scientists. 
 
The main objective of the project is to advance understanding of the molecular basis of neuron-neuron recognition. Cell-cell interactions are mediated by protein-protein interactions and the long-range goal of the research is to understand the underlying mechanisms. Specifically, how do protein-protein interactions involving cell surface proteins mediate highly specific cell-cell interactions. Given the complexity of the nervous system, neuron-neuron interactions offer a unique challenge in this regard. The research focuses on the clustered Protocadherins (Pcdhs) that establish a unique identity for individual vertebrate neurons allowing them to distinguish "self" from "non-self". These are neuronal barcoding proteins. The research involves computational studies to determine how homophilic specificity is coded on Pcdh-Pcdh interfaces, the design of mutants to test the hypotheses that are generated, and their testing experimentally. A second focus of the research is to elucidate the molecular basis of neuronal barcoding. A novel chain termination mechanism based on the assembly of crystalline-like "molecular zippers" in cell-cell interfaces has been proposed and is consistent with all available experimental data. The model will now be explored with multi-scale simulations, and in vitro and in vivo experimental studies. Notably, the model introduces new concepts in the molecular basis of cell-cell recognition. This project is supported by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Biological Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

The main objective of the proposed research is to advance our understanding of the molecular basis of neuron-neuron recognition. Cell-cell adhesive specificity can ultimately be traced to protein-protein interactions between cell surface adhesion receptors. These proteins are organized into families that are closely related in sequence and structure.  In some cases, the proteins dimerize in trans (between different cells) promiscuously and mediate both homophilic interactions and heterophilic interactions with a subset of other family members. This molecular recognition is reflected in their behavior in vivo which often exploits both types of interactions. In only a few cases, for example the clustered protocadherins (cPcdhs), preliminary evidence suggests that these proteins exhibit homophilic trans binding, with no measurable heterophilic recognition, despite high sequence similarity between family members. Such precise specificity is required for the role of Pcdhs in establishing a unique identity for each vertebrate neuron (“neuronal barcoding”).

A major goal of this proposal is to understand the structural and energetic origins of the cis and trans binding specificity exhibited by cPcdhs and the DIP/Dpr families of invertebrate adhesion proteins.  A second major goal has been to understand the mechanism of neuronal barcoding (that provides each neuron with a unique identity) mediated by cPcdhs. The formation of ordered cPcdh lattices between cells is central to this process and, further, lattice formation appears to be a property of many other cell-surface receptors. A longer-range goal is to understand how lattice formations mediates repulsion between neurites emanating from the same neuron. By studying lattice formation and downstream signaling process enabled by these lattices we hope to gain important insights as to essential cellular phenomena.

Our major findings include:

1. cPcdhs form linear zippers on liposome surfaces that then assemble into two dimensional arrays. These results confirm our previous model for the ability of neurons to distinguish self from non-self which in turn is a crucial feature in the development of the nervous system.

2. Designing mutant proteins with altered binding interactions allowed us to relate molecular properties to nervous system development.

3. We elucidated how adhesion proteins are tuned by evolution to be highly specific and, in turn, accounted for the need for such specificity in highly specific neuron-neuron recognition.

4. In collaboration with the Troyanovsky lab we demonstrated that adherens junctions play a role in the transmission of force from cell to cell and that their structured extracellular lattice places constraints on the association of interacellular proteins with the junction.

5. We developed new simulation methodologies that describe the assembly of ordered 2D lattices in the interfacial region between two interacting cells.

 

Intellectual Merit

            The intellectual merit of the proposal is derived from a number of factors: a) This is a unique research program that spans the range from fundamental biophysics to in vivo cell behavior. b) Theory and simulations are fully integrated with our experimental program to an extent not usually realized. c) The goal of relating molecular to cellular properties is also unique and success in this endeavor has the potential to reveal truly novel biophysical and biological insights. d) Our focus on the molecular basis of neuron-neuron recognition is quite novel. This is not a well-studied area that offers exciting opportunities for discovery. e) The insights we gain will lead to the identification of new principles of molecular recognition and of cell-cell recognition.

 

Broader Impacts

Our work on the molecular basis of cell-cell recognition has had significant impact in many different fields due in large part to the generality of the phenomena we are studying, the uniqueness of our approach and by our demonstration of the importance of structural biology and molecular biophysics in fields where they have, for the most part, been absent. This is highlighted by the collaborations described in the context of the current proposal which involve fields such as Drosophila genetics and nervous system development and neuron-neuron interactions in vertebrates. Moreover, the mutants we have designed are being used in many other labs and, we would argue, the principles we have uncovered have impacted research in diverse fields.

In terms of training, students and postdocs emerge from our lab with a deep appreciation of both computational and experimental work thus providing exemplars for broadly trained interdisciplinary scientists. Experimental and computational scientists interact closely, attend weekly joint seminars and publish joint papers. I think there are very few examples of labs that are truly integrated in this way. Our lab has produced outstanding graduate students and postdocs, many of whom have gone on to highly successful scientific careers. Women scientists constitute about 50% of our lab. We also devote time and resources in training high school and undergraduate students, many of whom are under-represented minorities.
